Award.AwardTitle: Continuous, Economical Manufacture of Nanocrystals for Future Industries and Medicine

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanocrystals or nanoparticles continue to evolve in technological relevance, with application in fields as diverse as energy (solar energy harvesting), environment (safer municipal water treatment), medicine (tumor diagnostics and treatments) and microelectronics (mobile devices and memory). These small particles, ranging in size from a few nanometers to almost a micron, serve many purposes, and in most cases it is their small size that yields unique material properties and functionality that are unattainable with the same material with a larger size. These properties promise extensive market potential and corresponding societal impact should scalable manufacturing processes be put into place that can provide large quantities of material at low cost with high quality, all the while limiting the environmental impact of their production. This award supports fundamental studies to provide a versatile manufacturing platform for the continuous production of high quality nanocrystals. Such a platform will permit economically-attractive and distributed, rather than centralized, production that can be utilized for on-demand applications, similar to the promise of 3D printing. The ability to produce customized nanocrystals in a rapid, cost effective fashion, as is possible with a membrane reactor concept, can be a significant advance in the evolving 21st century U.S. manufacturing infrastructure.

The routine production of well-defined nanoparticles remains a significant challenge, because of the interplay between equilibrium constraints and rate-based reaction and mass transfer processes. Typically, a trade-off exists between the achievable product quantity and quality, with higher production rates resulting in diminished control of nanocrystals' size, morphology, uniformity and the associated material properties. To address this ongoing challenge, the team will use experimentation, modeling, in-depth materials characterization, and creative system design, to confront the significant scientific and engineering questions with respect to the coupling of the membrane's geometric degrees-of-freedom to the hydrodynamic aspects of a flow system, and the specific chemical reactions, in order to synthesize nanocrystals with desirable material properties. New phenomena may also be uncovered related to how the nanometer size of the "surface reaction domains" on the membrane's porous surface can further affect how the critical stoichiometry for a reaction (or other phase transition) is reached and exceeded. The feasibility and scalability of this manufacturing innovation will be demonstrated through the manufacture of magnetite, silver, gold, and halogen-stabilized chalcogenide nanocrystals, all regarded as technologically significant nanomaterials that are beginning to impact a number of key industries.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanocrystals (aka nanoparticles, NPs) are of interest because they adhere to quantum rather than classical Newtonian mechanics. Because of this, materials at the nanoscale have different electrical, thermal, magnetic, optical, and mechanical properties than in the bulk. NPs are playing a major role in future technologies: in medicine, they can improve therapeutic effects or decrease unwanted side effects; and outside of medicine, nano-sized materials are being studied for a variety of applications including catalysts, electronics, ceramics, sensors, pigments, and in spectroscopy. Notwithstanding their importance, and that there are companies selling useful NPs, they are still expensive, and it is difficult to produce large quantities of product to precise specifications. An ideal process would be tunable for producing a variety of nominal sizes, having a narrow size distribution, and with a scalable process.

The co-PIs suggested that membrane contactor/reactors are attractive for production of NPs for several reasons, foremost of which is that membrane devices are easily scalable, for example, to have more reaction surface area, another membrane module can simply be added to an array. In addition, membranes can provide fixed and well-defined reaction sites at their surface pores. This scalable nano-manufacturing award enabled the proof-of-concept demonstration of a membrane contactor/reactor producing both silver (biocide end-uses) and magnetite (medical imaging end-uses) NPs by fixed interfacial contacting of immiscible phases across a membrane. Over the lifetime of the award, we furthered fundamental knowledge, and investigated prototype equipment and operating protocols that could enable translation of this idea into commonplace industrial manufacturing. The scientific outputs of the award included a published review paper elucidating the fundamental rationales for how membrane reactors can advance NP manufacturing and a presentation at a major society conference. Also, the project identified many hurdles that can help others proceed more effectively in the future. An additional manuscript is planned.

In addition to the direct societal value of the supported research, the broad-based benefits of this project included three diverse undergraduate students who assisted in the research, and not only helped define our experimental protocols, but also advanced their professional trajectories. Furthermore, partial support for the training of three graduate research assistants, two diverse post-doctoral assistants, and a graduate lab assistant was also provided. During the course of the award, we had conversations with several companies that either could supply membrane contactors or make NPs.


Last Modified: 12/30/2018
Modified by: John Pellegrino

Images (1 of )
  • Continuous flow w/ PP microporous membrane module: aqueous AgNO3 flows through fibers? lumen and organic solution of toluene heptanoic acid and TBAB, flows through shell, which leads to pinkish-orange suspension in organic phase with NPs.
    John Pellegrino
    John Pellegrino
    Continuous flow reactor, repeatable, Ag nanoparticle formation.
  • Recirculating flow w/ PP microporous membrane: demonstrates use of polymeric membrane for dispersion of NH3 across microporous membrane thickness into aqueous Fe2+ and Fe3+ salts. Residence time was ~10 s and magnetite formed immediately and ripened during further recirculation.
    John Pellegrino
    Copyrighted
    John Pellegrino
    Flow reactor for magnetite (Fe3O4) nanoparticles

Because of this, materials at the nanoscale have different electrical, thermal, magnetic, optical, and mechanical properties than in the bulk. NPs are playing a major role in future technologies: in medicine, they can improve therapeutic effects or decrease unwanted side effects; and outside of medicine, nano-sized materials are being studied for a variety of applications including catalysts, electronics, ceramics, sensors, pigments, and in spectroscopy. The co-PIs suggested that membrane contactor/reactors are attractive for production of NPs for several reasons, foremost of which is that membrane devices are easily scalable, for example, to have more reaction surface area, another membrane module can simply be added to an array. In addition to the direct societal value of the supported research, the broad-based benefits of this project included three diverse undergraduate students who assisted in the research, and not only helped define our experimental protocols, but also advanced their professional trajectories.
